Petar,

Thanks for the prompt response. Think I understand it now.

Also si=
nce found Ken's Phd thesis has it on page 43.
Adjusted fitness looks like a=
 weighted average rather than a simple
average (weighted by inter-species c=
ompatibility) (Ken's thesis p27).
Or will a simple average of the number of=
 individuals in the species
suffice?

Thanks

Mike




--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi, 
> 
> The=
 original fitness is simply the fitness of the individual you 
> assign bas=
ed ot your experiment :) 
> You divide this fitness by the number of indivi=
duals in the species 
> to get the adjusted fitness. 
> Note: all fitness v=
alues must be positive. 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aim=
ike002@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi, a beginners question on understanding  fitness =
sharing.
> > 
> > I've referrd to http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/m=
essage/2292
> > which gives an outline of speciation & I've also looked at =
some of 
> the
> > published 
> > papers, inc Ken's Phd thesis
> > 
> > Her=
es my understading:
> > 
> > At sach generation copy one genome from each s=
pecies forward into 
> the new 
> > generation. For all other genomes in th=
e new generation, assign them
> > into one
> > of the existing species usin=
g the compatibilty distance formula
> > delta =3D c1E/N +c2D/N + c3.W  . if=
 no compatibility match found, 
> start
> > a new species.
> > 
> > 
> > So=
 far so good (I hope)
> > 
> > Next Ken's phd thesis refer to a calculated =
fitness sharing 
> function fi.
> > 
> > This function gets adjusted to f(d=
ash)i by using the formula
> > 
> > f(dash)i =3D fi/Sigma (j=3D1 to n) sh(d=
elta)(i,j)
> > 
> > 
> > The bit I don't understand is what the the origina=
l fitness fi is 
> and
> > how its calculated.
> > 
> > (Is it supposed to =
represent the phenotype/networks closeness to the
> > target output?
> > i.=
e. if a network was 90% accurate, would fi =3D 0.9 ??)
> > 
> > Appreciate =
any clarification
> > 
> > Thanks
> > 
> > Mike
> >
